item.title: By: Fi
item.dc:creator: Fi
item.description: <p>I think that the figures might have been mis-interpreted there. Doesn't it mean that 51.5% of babies born to couples living together are boys (therefore 48.5% are girls) and that 49.9% of babies born to couples not living together are boys (therefore 50.1% are girls)? </p><p>This is significant only because it suggests that there are ways to influence the gender of your child and that, if families continue to change, we could end up with a lot more females than males in future. Small percentages over a long time in a big population add up. </p><p>I might be wrong though!</p>
item.content:encoded:
I think that the figures might have been mis-interpreted there. Doesn’t it mean that 51.5% of babies born to couples living together are boys (therefore 48.5% are girls) and that 49.9% of babies born to couples not living together are boys (therefore 50.1% are girls)?

This is significant only because it suggests that there are ways to influence the gender of your child and that, if families continue to change, we could end up with a lot more females than males in future. Small percentages over a long time in a big population add up.

I might be wrong though!
